subsections.title: Definitions
subsections.content: Understanding key terms related to the theory.
points: Theory: A set of assumptions used to explain facts or events; can be proven true or false.
Continental Drift: The movement of continental landmasses over time.

subsections.title: Overview of the Continental Drift Theory
subsections.content: Explanation of how continents moved from one position to another.
points: Continents were once joined as one supercontinent called Pangaea.
Pangaea was surrounded by a super ocean called Panthalassa.
Alfred Wegener proposed the theory in 1915.
Pangaea broke into Laurasia (North) and Gondwana (South).
These later broke into modern continents like Africa, Asia, and South America.
Continents drift due to convection currents in the Earth's mantle.
Continents ride on moving plates over the asthenosphere.

subsections.title: Evidence Supporting the Theory
subsections.content: Scientific observations that support continental drift.
points: Southern continents fit together like puzzle pieces.
Similar rock structures and ages in Brazil and West Africa.
Matching rocks found in Argentina and South Africa.
Fossils of the same plants and animals found on different continents.
Fossilized trees in Antarctica suggest past warmer climate.
Coal found in Antarctica indicates past tropical environment.
Glacial deposits in the Congo Basin despite current hot climate.
Magnetism in ancient rocks aligns with Earth's historical magnetic field.

subsections.title: Weaknesses of the Theory
subsections.content: Limitations and criticisms of Wegener’s ideas.
points: Northern continents do not fit together as neatly as southern ones.
The theory lacks detailed explanatory mechanisms.
Fails to explain what happens to oceanic crust during movement.
No clear cause for the movement of continents was given.
Too general and not specific in its assumptions.
Some fossil and climate data suggest continents may have stayed in place.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Plate tectonics refers to the theory explaining the movement of large segments of the Earth's lithosphere, known as plates.
points: Plates are massive slabs that make up the Earth's crust.
They float and move on the semi-fluid asthenosphere below.

subsections.title: Types of Plates
subsections.content: There are two main types of tectonic plates.
points: Continental Plates: Thick, made of granite (SIAL), less dense.
Oceanic Plates: Thin, made of basalt (SIMA), more dense.

subsections.title: Examples of Plates
subsections.content: Major tectonic plates around the world include:
points: Continental: African Plate, Eurasian Plate, North American Plate.
Oceanic: Pacific Plate, Nazca Plate, Philippine Plate.

subsections.title: Causes of Plate Movements
subsections.content: Plate movement is driven by processes inside the Earth.
points: Convection currents in the mantle.
Heat and pressure from the Earth's core.
Gravity and slab pull at subduction zones.

subsections.title: Types of Plate Boundaries
subsections.content: Tectonic plates meet and interact at boundaries.
points: Convergent (Destructive): Plates collide, leading to subduction.
Divergent (Constructive): Plates move apart, new crust forms.
Transform (Conservative): Plates slide past each other.

subsections.title: Features Formed at Plate Boundaries
subsections.content: Different geological features are formed at different boundaries.
points: Convergent: Fold mountains, trenches, volcanic mountains.
Divergent: Oceanic ridges, rift valleys, block mountains.
Transform: Faults, earthquakes (no major landform).

subsections.title: Seafloor Spreading
subsections.content: This occurs when new oceanic crust is formed at mid-ocean ridges.
points: Molten material rises and solidifies into new crust.
Proves that tectonic plates are moving.

subsections.title: Evidence of Seafloor Spreading
subsections.content: Several observations support the theory.
points: Sediments near ridges are thinner and newer.
Rock ages increase with distance from the ridge.
Magnetic patterns in rocks change symmetrically from the ridge.

subsections.title: Positive Impacts on Environment
subsections.content: Some geological features benefit the natural environment.
points: Volcanic rocks improve soil fertility.
Mountains modify climate and provide water sources.
Rift valleys form lakes and rivers.

subsections.title: Negative Impacts on Environment
subsections.content: Some features negatively affect the environment.
points: Volcanoes release harmful gases.
Mountains cause erosion on slopes.
Earthquakes damage ecosystems.

subsections.title: Positive Effects on Human Activities
subsections.content: Tectonic features offer many benefits to people.
points: Tourism at mountains and volcanoes.
Rift valley lakes provide water.
Mountains offer rainfall and mineral resources.
Volcanism aids scientific research.

subsections.title: Negative Effects on Human Activities
subsections.content: Geological activity can be dangerous to humans.
points: Earthquakes and eruptions destroy property.
Landslides harm people and infrastructure.
Mountains hinder transport and communication.

subsections.title: Definition and Processes
subsections.content: Mountain building, also called orogeny, involves the formation of mountains through earth movements.
points: Orogeny refers to the uplifting or folding of rock masses to form mountains.
Major mountain building processes: Folding, Faulting, Volcanism, and Denudation.

subsections.title: Folding
subsections.content: Folding is the bending of crustal rocks due to compressional forces.
points: Forms fold mountains and valleys.
Anticline: upfold that forms a mountain.
Syncline: downfold that forms a valley.
Types of folds: Symmetrical, Overfold, Recumbent, Overthrust.

subsections.title: Features Formed by Folding
subsections.content: Folding creates several landforms.
points: Fold Mountains
Anticlines and Domes
Synclines and Basins
Trenches (on the seafloor)
Volcanoes

subsections.title: Fold Mountains
subsections.content: Fold mountains result from large-scale lateral crustal movements.
points: Caused by factors like mantle convection currents and crustal compression.
Old Fold Mountains: Rounded, low, denuded (e.g., Scottish Highlands, Urals).
Young Fold Mountains: High, rugged, recent (e.g., Himalayas, Andes, Alps, Rockies).

subsections.title: Faulting
subsections.content: Faulting is the breaking of the Earth's crust due to tension or compression.
points: Creates block mountains (horsts) and rift valleys.
Occurs along lines of weakness called faults.
Common features: escarpments, fault scarps, rift valley lakes.

subsections.title: Types of Faults
subsections.content: Different faults form under different stress conditions.
points: Normal Fault: caused by tension; central block sinks.
Reverse Fault: caused by compression; one block pushed over another.
Tear Fault (Strike-slip): caused by shearing forces; blocks move sideways.

subsections.title: Features Formed by Faulting
subsections.content: Faulting creates unique landforms.
points: Block Mountains or Horsts
Rift Valleys (e.g., Great East African Rift Valley)
Fault Scarps
Rift Valley Lakes (e.g., Lake Tanganyika, Lake Malawi)

subsections.title: Characteristics of Rift Valleys and Lakes
subsections.content: Rift valleys and associated lakes have distinctive features.
points: Rift valleys: long, narrow, steep sides, flat floors.
Rift valley lakes: long, narrow, and very deep.
Lake Tanganyika is the world’s deepest; Lake Malawi is third deepest.

subsections.title: Environmental Impacts of Faulting
subsections.content: Faulting affects the environment both positively and negatively.
points: Positive: mineral exposure, tourism from scenic block mountains, rainfall catchment areas.
Negative: earthquakes, landslides, climate variation across mountains, salty lakes in valleys.

subsections.title: Human Impact of Mountain Building
subsections.content: Mountain building affects human activities in multiple ways.
points: Positive: sources of rivers, water for irrigation, hydroelectricity, tourism, mineral extraction, fish from lakes.
Negative: transport barriers, earthquakes and landslides, communication difficulties, varying climates on mountain slopes.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Volcanism is the process by which magma and other associated materials rise into the Earth's crust. The materials include lava, ashes, gas, steam, hot water, and solid rock particles.
points: Also called vulcanicity or vulcanism.
Molten rock in the mantle is called magma.
Molten rock on the Earth’s surface is called lava.

subsections.title: Causes of Volcanism
subsections.content: Volcanism is caused by crustal disturbances and subduction of plates.
points: Deep faulting of the crust.
Plate subduction into the mantle.

subsections.title: Types of Lava
subsections.content: Lava is classified into basic and acid types based on temperature, fluidity, and composition.
points: Basic Lava – Highly hot and fluid, dark-colored, rich in iron and magnesium, forms lava plateaus.
Acid Lava – Thick and viscous, light-colored, rich in silica, explosive, forms steep-sided cones.

subsections.title: Volcano and Stages
subsections.content: A volcano is a vent or mountain formed by magma reaching the surface.
points: Active Volcano – Frequently erupts.
Dormant Volcano – May erupt in future; signs include geysers and fumaroles.
Extinct Volcano – Has not erupted in historical time; features are still visible.

subsections.title: Parts of a Volcano
subsections.content: The volcano has several distinct parts.
points: Vent – Fissure through which materials erupt.
Crater – Depression at the top.
Volcanic ash – Fine particles ejected.
Volcanic cone – Pile of materials around vent.

subsections.title: Intrusive Volcanic Features
subsections.content: These are formed when magma cools and solidifies underground.
points: Batholith – Large mass forming roots of mountains.
Laccolith – Smaller dome-shaped body.
Dyke – Vertical intrusion cutting across rock layers.
Sill – Horizontal intrusion between bedding planes.
Pipe – Channel of magma to surface.
Fumarole – Vent emitting steam.
Hot Spring – Quiet outpouring of hot water.
Geyser – Violent outburst of superheated water.

subsections.title: Extrusive Volcanic Features
subsections.content: These form when lava and materials erupt onto the surface.
points: Volcanic mountains
Volcanic plateaus or plains
Crater and caldera (larger depressions)
Hot springs
Geysers
Fumaroles

subsections.title: Types of Volcanoes
subsections.content: Volcanoes vary by shape, eruption style, and material composition.
points: Shield Volcano – Wide base, gentle slope, formed by fluid lava (e.g., Mauna Loa).
Cinder Cone – Steep sides, formed by explosive eruptions.
Composite Volcano – Tall, layered with lava and ash (e.g., Mt. Kilimanjaro).

subsections.title: Characteristics of Volcanic Mountains
subsections.content: Volcanic mountains have specific forms and landscape features.
points: Conical shape and symmetrical.
Often isolated.
Formed from repeated eruptions.

subsections.title: Effects of Volcanism
subsections.content: Volcanic activity has both beneficial and harmful effects.
points: Positive – Fertile soil, mineral resources, tourism, geothermal energy, new land formation.
Negative – Death and destruction, air pollution, transport barriers, restricted settlement.

subsections.title: Residual Mountains (Denudational)
subsections.content: Residual mountains are formed by erosion that leaves behind resistant rock.
points: Found on plains.
Rounded like islands (inselbergs).
Made of hard rocks such as granite.
Examples in Malawi: Bunda, Mulanje, Hora, Chiradzulu.

subsections.title: Importance of Denudation
subsections.content: Denudation contributes positively to human life and the environment.
points: Produces fertile soil for farming.
Provides timber, rocks, minerals.
Forms rivers for hydroelectricity.
Creates scenic areas for tourism.
Supports wildlife conservation.

subsections.title: Problems of Denudation
subsections.content: Denudation can also create environmental hazards.
points: Mudflows bury roads and homes.
Landslides and avalanches damage property and kill.
Soil erosion on slopes reduces land quality.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Earthquake refers to the sudden movement of the Earth's lithosphere. It is also defined as the shaking of the Earth's crust.

subsections.title: Causes of Earthquakes
subsections.content: Earthquakes are caused by natural and human activities, mainly occurring at plate boundaries where volcanism is common.
points: Plate shearing where plates grind each other.
Plate collision at a zone of subduction.
Volcanism.
Existence of faults.
Large scale mining and quarrying (human cause).

subsections.title: Nature of Earthquakes
subsections.content: Key terms and concepts related to the origin and impact of earthquakes.
points: Focus: the point in the lithosphere where earthquakes start (origin).
Epicenter: the point vertically above focus on the Earth's surface where shock waves hit; experiences most damage.
Magnitude: total energy released by the earthquake.
Seismic waves carry earthquake energy; classified into body waves and surface waves.

subsections.title: Types of Seismic Waves
subsections.content: Seismic waves transmit energy through the Earth’s interior and surface.
points: Body waves operate inside the Earth and include primary (fastest, travel through solids and liquids) and secondary waves (slower, shake crust laterally and vertically).
Surface waves cause lateral and vertical movements on the surface; include Love waves (faster) and Rayleigh waves.

subsections.title: Intensity and Measurement
subsections.content: Measures and instruments used to quantify earthquakes.
points: Intensity: degree of damage caused on Earth's surface.
Seismograph: instrument measuring earthquake magnitude by recording vibrations.
Richter scale: magnitude scale from 1 to 9; higher values indicate more destructive earthquakes.

subsections.title: Pacific Ring of Fire
subsections.content: Region associated with frequent volcanism and earthquakes.
points: Belt across Southern Europe and Southern Asia.
Belt in the Southern Pacific Ocean including Japan, Philippines, and East Indies.
West coastal margins of North and South America.

subsections.title: Effects of Earthquakes
subsections.content: Earthquakes impact the environment and human life in several ways.
points: Cause landslides, especially on hillsides.
Lowering and raising of coastal rocks and the sea floor.
Vertical and horizontal displacement of the lithosphere.
Fires in cities due to broken power lines.
Generation of tsunamis (huge ocean waves).
Death of people and destruction of property.

subsections.title: Relationship Among Earthquakes, Fold Mountains and Volcanoes
subsections.content: These geological phenomena are interconnected.
points: All occur due to crustal movements.
All mainly take place at plate boundaries.
They can cause each other to occur.

subsections.title: Precautionary Measures Against Earthquakes
subsections.content: Safety tips and government roles to reduce earthquake risks.
points: Stand in open spaces away from buildings and trees during an earthquake.
Cover yourself with a cushion or mattress.
Make settlements away from earthquake and volcanic zones.
Construct buildings with strong but lightweight materials to resist collapse.
Governments should establish early warning systems.
Ensure quick search and rescue operations.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
points: Describe the main types of rocks.
Explain the formation of rocks.
Identify the characteristics and samples of each type of rocks.
Examine the importance of rocks to life and human activities.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: The lithosphere is made up of a hard mass of rocks which is the parent material from which soil is formed. The main rocks of the lithosphere are sedimentary, igneous, and metamorphic.

subsections.title: Sedimentary Rocks
subsections.content: Sedimentary rock is the most dominant rock on the Earth's surface. It is the product of weathering. Solid rock is broken down into smaller particles called clastics. These particles are carried by agents of erosion and deposited in geosynclines where they are compacted and cemented to form sedimentary rock.
points: Mechanical formation produces clastic sedimentary rocks.
Examples include conglomerate, breccia, siltstone, sandstone, and shale.

subsections.title: Types of Sedimentary Rocks
points: Clastic Sedimentary or Mechanically Formed Rocks: formed from weathering materials such as sand, silt, clay, and gravel. Examples: conglomerate, breccia, siltstone, sandstone, shale.

Non-Clastic or Chemically Formed Rocks: formed by precipitation of minerals, evaporation, and deposition of organic matter. Examples: chert (flint), alabaster, salt, gypsum, peat (lignite or coal), limestone.

subsections.title: Characteristics of Sedimentary Rocks
points: They are layered or stratified due to periodic deposition.
They contain fossils, which are buried remains of dead plants and animals.
They are generally non-crystalline, especially clastic rocks.

subsections.title: Igneous Rocks
subsections.content: Igneous rocks are formed from cooling magma that solidifies in the Earth's lithosphere, often as a result of volcanic eruptions. Formed through melting and cooling processes.

subsections.title: Types of Igneous Rocks
points: Extrusive or Volcanic Rocks: formed by rapid cooling of magma on the Earth's surface, resulting in fine textures. Examples: obsidian, scoria, rhyolite, andesite, basalt.
Intrusive or Plutonic Rocks: formed by slow cooling of magma below the Earth's surface, resulting in coarse textures. Examples: granite, gabbro, diorite, peridotite.
Hypabyssal Rocks: formed when magma cools in fissures or channels connecting surface and magma chamber.

subsections.title: Characteristics of Igneous Rocks
points: They are crystalline.
They are not layered.
They do not contain fossils.

subsections.title: Metamorphic Rocks
subsections.content: Metamorphic rocks originate from sedimentary or igneous rocks that have been altered by heat, pressure, and water.
points: Dynamic Metamorphism: alteration due to pressure.
Thermal or Contact Metamorphism: alteration due to heat, causing recrystallization.
Regional Metamorphism: alteration caused by both heat and pressure over large areas.
Metamorphism caused by water dissolves and rearranges minerals.

subsections.title: Importance of Rocks
points: Used in construction.
Parent material for soil formation.
Contain minerals valuable for mining.
Hold underground water (e.g., aquifers).
Beautify the countryside.

subsections.title: Rock Cycle
subsections.content: The rock cycle is a continuous process by which rocks are formed from each other.

subsections.title: Shields
subsections.content: Shields are parts of continents made up of very ancient rocks formed billions of years ago.
points: Located away from plate boundaries.
Very stable, not affected by geological activities such as earthquakes and volcanism.
Associated with low plateaus and plains.
Little or no active geological activity like folding, faulting, and volcanism.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the term riverine landform.
Identify riverine features from the map.
Explain the formation of riverine landforms.
Explain the importance of riverine landforms.

subsections.title: Definition of River and Related Terms
subsections.content: River refers to the surface run-off confined in natural channels called a valley. It is a natural waterway that follows the direction of a slope.
points: Source of a river is the point where rivers start, which can be a highland or lowland.
A highland that forms a source is called a watershed or divide.
River basin is the area drained by rivers; both highland and basin are called catchment area.
Confluence is the point where two rivers join.
Tributary is a river that joins the main river at a confluence.

subsections.title: River Courses
subsections.content: A river course is the path taken by a river, divided into three main stages:
points: Upper course (Youthful stage)
Middle course (Mature stage)
Lower course (Old stage)

subsections.title: Upper Course or Youthful Stage
subsections.content: Mountain stage of the river characterized by vertical erosion and fast-moving water due to steep slopes. Main features include:
points: V-shaped valley formed by vertical erosion.
Potholes: circular depressions formed by grinding effect of pebbles.
Gorges: deep, narrow valleys with steep sides; larger gorges are canyons.
Interlocking spurs: bands of hard rock projecting into the valley.
Cliffs: steep land facing the river.
Flood plain: low-lying area covered by sediments.
Rapids and waterfalls caused by resistant rock breaks.
Tributary: streams joining the main river.

subsections.title: Waterfalls and Related Features
subsections.content: Waterfalls form where resistant rocks cause vertical drops.
points: Plunge pools: deep depressions at base of waterfalls, deepened by hydraulic action.
Interlocking spurs cause winding river courses.

subsections.title: Middle Course
subsections.content: Water causes lateral erosion forming U-shaped valleys; deposition of heavy load begins.
points: Meanders: river bends formed when obstacles or deposits block the course.

subsections.title: Lower Course or Old Stage
subsections.content: Main function is deposition of sediments. Main features include:
points: Ox-bow Lakes: formed by deposition sealing meander necks, isolating water bodies.
Levees: raised river banks formed by deposit accumulation.
Flood plains: flat, gently sloping areas flooded during river overflow.
River braiding: splitting and rejoining of channels in lower course.
Delta: triangular alluvial area at river mouth.

subsections.title: Formation of Ox-bow Lake
points: Development of meanders.
Large load deposited at meander neck.
Deposition seals neck separating meander from river.
Flooding straightens the river course.

subsections.title: Types of Deltas
points: Estuarine delta: river submerged into main water body (e.g., Seine, Ob).
Cuspate delta: pointed shape (e.g., Tiber).
Bird’s foot delta: silt deposits forming finger-like projections (e.g., Mississippi).
Arcuate delta: triangular with many distributaries (e.g., Nile, Ganges).

subsections.title: Conditions for Delta Formation
points: River must carry a large load.
Water velocity must be low.
Deposition must exceed sediment removal by currents.
Shallow water at river mouth is necessary.

subsections.title: Stages of Delta Development
points: Deposition at river mouth.
Formation of distributaries.
Further deposition and vegetation growth.

subsections.title: Economic Importance of Rivers
points: Waterfalls generate hydroelectric power.
Deltas and flood plains provide fertile land for agriculture.
Lower course facilitates water transport.
Rivers are sources of fish.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Identify coastal landforms.
Explain how coastal landforms are formed.
Explain the importance of coastal landforms.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Coast is the strip of land that borders the sea. Shore is the strip of land between low and high water levels. Coastal landforms are features formed alongside the sea or lake.
points: Deposition and erosion are the main processes forming coastal landforms.
Prominent coastal features include headlands, lagoons, spits, islands, tombolos, peninsulas, caves, arches, stacks, stumps, fjords, straits, and estuaries.

subsections.title: Headland and Bay
subsections.content: Headland is a piece of land or rock projecting into the water from the mainland, resistant to erosion. Larger than a headland is a cape.
points: Example of a cape: Cape Maclear in Mangoche.
Bay is a water body extending into the mainland located between two headlands.

subsections.title: Caves, Arches, Stacks, and Stumps
subsections.content: Caves are holes curved into headlands by wave erosion. Enlarged caves can form arches.
points: Stack is a rock detached from cliffs by wave erosion of an arch roof.
Stacks erode further into stumps, visible only at low water.
Blow hole is a vertical hole connecting a cave roof.
These features develop along rock cracks where erosion and weathering are active.

subsections.title: Peninsula and Tombolo
subsections.content: Peninsula is land partly surrounded by water and connected to mainland by an isthmus.
points: Tombolo is a sandbar joining an island to the mainland, formed by longshore drift.
Islands attached to mainland by tombolos are called tied lands.

subsections.title: Geo and Beach
subsections.content: Geo is a long narrow inlet formed by collapse of a cave or arch roof.
points: Beach is a gently sloping coastal area with deposits of sand and pebbles formed by wave action.
Example: Livingstonia Beach, popular with tourists.

subsections.title: Spit and Lagoon
subsections.content: Spit is a low, narrow ridge of sand attached to land at one end, formed by deposition through longshore drift.
points: Spits often form at river mouths.
Lagoon is a smaller water body separated from main water body by sandbars or narrow land.
Examples of lagoons in Malawi: Chia and Bana.

subsections.title: Fjords, Strait, and Estuary
subsections.content: Fjords are valleys carved by glaciers and flooded by water.
points: Strait is a narrow water body connecting two larger water bodies, e.g., Suez Canal.
Estuary is a water body at a river mouth where freshwater mixes with seawater.

subsections.title: Islands
subsections.content: Island is land completely surrounded by water. Peninsulas may become islands if the isthmus erodes.
points: Types of islands:
1. Continental islands – near continental shelf close to mainland.
2. Volcanic islands – formed at seabed especially at diverging plate boundaries.
3. Coral islands – formed by corals whose limy skeletons cement to form limestone.
4. Barrier islands – narrow islands parallel to coast, protecting mainland from ocean waves.

subsections.title: Importance of Coastal Landforms
points: Provide habitat for wildlife such as fish, reptiles, and birds.
Continental shelves and bays are suitable for port construction.
Support agriculture.
Used for hydroelectricity generation; lagoons and estuaries can be dammed for tidal energy.
Attract tourists due to rich biodiversity.
Good fishing grounds due to shallowness and abundant planktons.

topics.title: Relief Features of the Ocean Basin

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the relief features of ocean basin.
Explain the terms ocean currents, drifts and streams.
Identify the major ocean currents of the world.
Explain causes of ocean currents.
Explain factors that influence the direction of ocean currents.
Describe the effects of ocean currents.

subsections.title: Definition of Ocean Basin
subsections.content: Ocean basin is a depression on the Earth’s surface where the oceans exist.
points: The main oceans on Earth are Indian, Pacific, Atlantic and Antarctic.

subsections.title: Nature of Ocean Floor
subsections.content: The ocean floor is made up of various features including continental shelf, continental slope, continental rise, abyssal plains, oceanic ridges, and trenches.

subsections.title: Continental Shelf
subsections.content: It is a gently sloping platform extending from the continental landmass and ends at the steep continental slope.
points: It is gently sloping.
It has a fairly smooth surface.
It is shallow.
It is rich in deposits from rivers.

subsections.title: Importance of Continental Shelf
subsections.content: The continental shelf is important for several reasons:
points: Good fishing ground because shallow water allows sunlight to penetrate, stimulating plankton growth which feeds fish.
Provides good natural harbors for ships.
Used for oil drilling.

subsections.title: Continental Slope
subsections.content: A steep, nearly vertical slope lying between the continental shelf and deep ocean water.
points: Contains submarine canyons.

subsections.title: Continental Rise
subsections.content: A gently sloping part of the seabed lying between the continental slope and abyssal plain.

subsections.title: Oceanic Ridge
subsections.content: An underwater mountain range such as the Hawaiian and Mid-Atlantic Ridges.

subsections.title: Abyssal Plain
subsections.content: The deepest, extensively flat and darkest part of the seabed.
points: Has a relatively smooth floor.
Covered by sediments and organic matter.
Found at depths between 2000m and 3000m.
Covered by basaltic lava.
Contains hills and ridges.

subsections.title: Trench or Oceanic Trench
subsections.content: A long and narrow valley at the bottom of the ocean; the deepest part of the ocean.
points: Examples include Mariana and Tonga Trenches in the Pacific Ocean.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Ocean currents refer to the circulation of water around the ocean in a regular pattern. Water moves vertically (mixing) and horizontally.
points: Continuous flow of ocean current in a definite direction with greater velocity is called a stream, e.g., Gulf Stream.

subsections.title: Classification of Ocean Currents
subsections.content: Ocean currents are classified according to temperature and depth.

subsections.title: Types of Ocean Currents by Temperature
subsections.content: There are warm and cold ocean currents depending on their temperature origin.
points: Warm Ocean Currents originate in tropical regions where temperature is always high.
Examples: Brazilian, North Atlantic Drift, Mozambican, Kuroshiwo, East Australian Currents.
All warm currents are located on eastern coasts of continents except Kuroshiwo.
Cold Ocean Currents originate in polar regions with low temperatures.
Examples: Californian, Peruvian, Labrador, Canaries, East Australian, Kamchatka Currents.

subsections.title: Types of Ocean Currents by Depth
subsections.content: Ocean currents are also classified by depth into surface and deep currents.
points: Surface Currents circulate up to 400m depth and move over longer distances.
Deep Currents move below 400m depth, slower than surface currents.
Deep currents are caused by temperature and salinity differences; cold and salty water sinks.

subsections.title: Causes of Ocean Currents
subsections.content: Several factors cause ocean currents.
points: Temperature: Warm water rises as it is lighter; cold water sinks as it is denser.
Salinity: Water with high salt content is denser and sinks; freshwater rises.
Prevailing Winds: Winds force water to flow in the same direction; currents caused by wind are called drifts, e.g., North Atlantic Drift.

Earth’s Rotation: Ferrell’s Law of Deflection causes currents to deflect right in Northern Hemisphere and left in Southern Hemisphere, creating clockwise and anticlockwise flows respectively. This effect is called Coriolis Force.

subsections.title: Factors Influencing the Direction of Ocean Currents
subsections.content: The direction of ocean currents is influenced by:
points: Earth's rotation causing clockwise flow in Northern Hemisphere and anticlockwise in Southern Hemisphere.
Shape of continents guiding currents along coastlines.
Prevailing winds pushing water in consistent directions.

subsections.title: Effects of Ocean Currents
subsections.content: Ocean currents affect fishing, shipping, and climate.
points: On Fishing: Meeting of cold and warm currents creates rich fishing grounds, e.g., Japan due to Kamchatka and Kuroshiwo currents.
On Shipping: Fog forms where cold and warm currents meet, reducing visibility and causing accidents; ships moving against currents consume more fuel; strong currents can submerge ships.

On Climate: Warm currents raise temperatures in temperate regions; cold currents lower temperatures in tropical regions and prevent precipitation causing deserts on western coasts; meeting of currents forms dense fog near the ground.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the term air pressure.
Explain factors that affect air pressure.
Locate the main air pressure belts on world maps.
Account for the distribution of pressure belts in the world.
Explain how Ferrel’s Law of Deflection (Coriolis force) affects prevailing winds.

subsections.title: Definition of Air Pressure
subsections.content: Air pressure is the force exerted by air at any point on Earth. The mixture of gases covering the Earth’s surface is called the atmosphere.
points: Atmosphere gases include nitrogen (78%), oxygen (21%), and other gases (1%) such as neon, helium, argon, methane, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide.

subsections.title: Factors that Influence Air Pressure
subsections.content: Several factors influence air pressure:
points: Altitude: Air pressure decreases with increase in altitude as air molecules are concentrated more at low levels.
Temperature: Air pressure decreases as temperature increases due to molecules spreading out; it increases when temperature decreases.
Rotation of the Earth: Air spreads out at the equator, reducing pressure, and concentrates at the poles, increasing pressure.
Wind Speed: Strong winds decrease air pressure by scattering air molecules.
Amount of Water Vapour: Increased water vapour decreases air pressure.

subsections.title: Pressure Belts and Prevailing Winds
subsections.content: The main pressure belts on Earth are:

subsections.title: Equatorial Low Pressure Belt
subsections.content: Also known as the Doldrums, located between 10° north and south of the Equator.
points: Sun is vertically overhead.
Receives convection rainfall.
Air rises creating low air pressure.
Trade wind masses meet forming the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ).
Tropical cyclones develop here.

subsections.title: Sub-Tropical High Pressure Belt
subsections.content: Located between 30° south and north of the Equator.
points: Air is descending causing desert conditions (e.g., Sahara, Namib, Atacama, Kalahari).
Also called the Horse Latitude.
Skies are clear with high temperatures.
Anticyclones develop here.

subsections.title: Temperate Low Pressure Belt
subsections.content: Located between 60° and 70° north and south of the Equator.
points: Air is descending creating low air pressure.
Cold and warm air masses converge here.
Temperate cyclones (depressions) form due to the meeting of air masses.

subsections.title: Polar High Pressure Belt
subsections.content: Found at 90° north and south of the Equator.
points: Air pressure is very high due to low temperatures.
Air occupies very small space.

subsections.title: Seasonal Pressure Variations
subsections.content: Pressure changes according to seasons:
points: In July, low air pressure occurs in the Northern Hemisphere (summer), and high pressure in the Southern Hemisphere (winter).
In January, high air pressure occurs in the Southern Hemisphere (winter), and low pressure in the Northern Hemisphere (summer).

subsections.title: Effects of Ferrel’s Law of Deflection (Coriolis Force) on Prevailing Winds
subsections.content: Ferrel’s Law states that moving bodies like wind and water are deflected:
points: To the right in the Northern Hemisphere.
To the left in the Southern Hemisphere.
Resulting in clockwise wind rotation in the Northern Hemisphere.
Resulting in anticlockwise wind rotation in the Southern Hemisphere.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the term prevailing winds.
Explain the different types of prevailing winds.
Explain how prevailing winds are influenced by the air pressure belts.

subsections.title: Definition of Prevailing Winds
subsections.content: Prevailing winds are the winds that blow more frequently than any other wind in the region.

subsections.title: Types of Prevailing Winds
subsections.content: There are three main types of prevailing winds:
points: Trade Winds
Westerlies
Easterlies or Polar Winds

subsections.title: Trade Winds
subsections.content: Trade Winds blow from the Horse Latitude towards the Doldrums.
points: They are constant in both speed and direction.
They contain cyclones and anticyclones.
They bring rainfall to eastern coasts of continents and become dry on western coasts.
Deflected to the right in the Northern Hemisphere to become North East Trade Winds, and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere to become South East Trade Winds.
More pronounced over oceans than continents.

subsections.title: Westerly Winds
subsections.content: Westerly Winds blow from the Horse Latitude towards the Temperate Low Pressure Belt.
points: They are variable in both speed and direction.
They contain depressions and cyclones.
Bring rainfall to western coasts of continents, especially in Mediterranean climates.
Called South Westerlies in the Northern Hemisphere and North Westerlies in the Southern Hemisphere.

subsections.title: Polar or Easterly Winds
subsections.content: Polar Winds blow from Polar High Pressure regions towards Temperate Low Pressure areas.
points: They are bitterly cold.
Better developed in the Southern Hemisphere due to more water than land.
Called North Easterlies (North East Polar Wind) in the Northern Hemisphere and South Easterlies (South East Polar Wind) in the Southern Hemisphere.

subsections.title: Environmental Influence of Prevailing Winds
subsections.content: Prevailing winds have both positive and negative effects.
points: Positive influences:
Westerly wind belts support long-distance flights; trans-oceanic and trans-continental flights use less fuel and take less time flying with westerlies.
Trade Wind belts facilitated westward travel in the days of sailing by dhows.
The meeting of cold Polar Winds and Westerlies creates fronts that bring precipitation.
Off-shore Trade Winds cause desert conditions on western coasts of continents.
Strong winds can cause soil erosion.
Trade Wind zones are prone to tropical cyclones like hurricanes and typhoons.
Trade wind convergence (ITCZ) brings frontal rainfall in tropical regions.
Steady Trade Winds and clear weather favor mariners.
Negative influences:
Strong head-on winds slow down water and air transport, increasing fuel consumption.
Trade Winds can bring destructive winds, e.g., hurricanes in America.
Polar Winds cause blizzards with harmful effects on humans.

subsections.title: How Pressure Belts Influence Prevailing Winds
subsections.content: Pressure belts determine the movement and behavior of prevailing winds.
points: Equatorial regions have low air pressure due to high temperatures and sun being vertically overhead.
Air occupies large surface area in tropical regions, causing low pressure.
Poles have high air pressure due to cold temperatures and concentrated air molecules.
Winds blow outward from high pressure belts and inward towards low pressure belts.
Earth’s rotation deflects winds to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere (Coriolis effect).
Winds converge in low pressure belts and diverge in high pressure belts.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the term air mass.
Explain the main types of air mass.
Explain the weather associated with air mass.

subsections.title: Definition of Air Mass
subsections.content: An air mass is a large body of air with uniform temperature, humidity, and originality.
points: Classified by temperature: cold and warm air masses.
Classified by originality: polar and tropical air masses.
Classified by moisture content: moist and dry air masses.

subsections.title: Classification of Air Masses
subsections.content: Air masses are classified based on latitude and surface nature of the region.
points: Latitudinal Position:
Arctic (A) or Antarctic (AA) air mass
Polar (P) air mass
Tropical (T) air mass
Surface Nature:
Continental (c) air mass: originates from land surface
Maritime (m) air mass: originates from sea

subsections.title: Types of Air Masses Based on Both Latitude and Surface
subsections.content: Types of air masses combining latitudinal and surface characteristics:
points: Continental Tropical (cT): hot, dry, unstable; develops over tropical land; blows towards polar air mass.
Maritime Tropical (mT): warm, moist, unstable; develops over tropical water; blows towards polar air mass.
Maritime Polar (mP): cold, moist, unstable; develops over polar seas; blows towards tropics.
Continental Polar (cP): cold, dry, stable; develops in Arctic and Antarctic; blows towards tropics; associated with cold and dry weather.

subsections.title: Stable Air Mass
subsections.content: A stable air mass resists rising and tends to sink when not forced upward.
points: Poor visibility on land due to dust particles.
Fog on or near land surface.
Does not easily produce rain.

subsections.title: Unstable Air Mass
subsections.content: An unstable air mass continues to rise because it is warmer than surrounding air.
points: Brings heavy rainfall accompanied by thunderstorms in warm and humid regions.
Characterized by cumulus clouds that produce rain and thunderstorms.
Good surface visibility.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the term fronts.
Explain the formation of fronts.
Identify characteristics of different types of fronts.
Describe the weather associated with different types of fronts.
Explain the ITCZ and its impact on weather.

subsections.title: Definition of Front
subsections.content: A front is the region where cold and warm air masses meet or the line that separates them.
points: The Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is similar to a front but forms when tropical air masses of uniform temperature meet.
Both fronts and ITCZ bring cyclonic rainfall.

subsections.title: Types of Fronts
subsections.content: There are four main types of fronts:
points: Cold Front: formed where cold air pushes into warm air.
Warm Front: formed where warm air overtakes or pushes into cold air.
Occluded Front: formed when cold and warm fronts catch up with each other, forcing warm air upwards.
Stationary Front: formed when cold and warm air masses meet but neither is strong enough to push the other.

subsections.title: Cold Front
subsections.content: Characteristics of cold front:
points: Frontal surface is very steep.
Moves faster than warm front.
Has tall clouds.
Brings heavy rains but for a short time.
More violent and moves quickly compared to warm front.

subsections.title: Warm Front
subsections.content: Characteristics of warm front:
points: Frontal surface is less steep.
Moves slowly.
Less violent than cold front.
Widespread cloud cover bringing heavy showers.

subsections.title: Occluded Front
subsections.content: When cold and warm fronts catch up, warm air caught between them is forced upward.
points: Two types: Cold occlusion and Warm occlusion.

subsections.title: Stationary Front
subsections.content: When cold and warm air masses meet but neither pushes the other, the front remains mostly stationary.
points: Water vapor condenses into precipitation.
Brings clouds and rain for many days.

subsections.title: Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ)
subsections.content: Region where tropical air masses meet causing weather changes.
points: Warm, moist air rises over cold air causing condensation and rainfall.
Shifts seasonally following the overhead sun due to Earth's revolution.
Brings frontal or cyclonic rainfall, e.g., in January in the southern hemisphere.
Shifting ITCZ causes seasonal rainfall pattern changes.

subsections.title: Additional Weather Phenomena
subsections.content: Related weather patterns influenced by air masses and fronts:
points: Congo Air: moist north-westerly wind from Atlantic Ocean via Zaire bringing frontal rainfall in Malawi.
Tropical Cyclone: intense low-pressure cell originating from the Indian Ocean, moving east to west, bringing heavy rainfall to southern Malawi.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the meaning of the term local winds.
Explain the characteristics of local winds.
Explain the occurrence of local winds.
Explain the occurrence of land and sea breezes.
Explain the influence of land and sea breezes on local weather and human activities.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Local winds are winds that affect a limited area and blow for a short period of time. They are influenced by the immediate relief of the local area.
points: They moderate unpleasant and unhealthy weather conditions.
They remove pollutants such as fumes from their sources.
They modify local temperature by bringing a cooling effect.

subsections.title: Types of Local Winds
subsections.content: Different types of local winds include:
points: Monsoon winds
Descending winds
Depression winds
Breezes
Valley winds (breezes)
Mountain winds (breezes)

subsections.title: Monsoon Winds
subsections.content: Monsoon wind is a strong system of seasonal wind that moves in opposite directions according to changes in seasons.
points: Monsoon means seasonal reversal of wind.
Caused by seasonal temperature differences between South Eastern Asia and the Indian/Pacific oceans.
In summer, high land temperatures cause winds to move from sea to land, bringing rainfall.
In winter, land temperature is lower than water, causing offshore monsoon winds.

subsections.title: Descending Winds and Depressions
subsections.content: These are warm winds formed by compression as they descend on the leeward side of mountains.
points: Examples of descending winds: Chinook, Chiperone, and Berg.
If crossing a sea, these winds collect moisture and become moist.
Examples: Santa Ana, Zonda, Laveche, Sirocco, Brickfielder, Harmattan.

subsections.title: The Harmattan
subsections.content: A dry, dusty, and hot wind blowing from the Sahara Desert.
points: Causes dust storms reducing visibility and negatively affecting air transport.
Called 'wind doctor' in the Guinea coast as it causes evaporation, bringing cooling.
Reduces humidity in the Equatorial climate of Guinea coast.

subsections.title: Cold Winds
subsections.content: Strong, gusty, and bitterly cold winds.
points: Examples: Pampero, Mistral, Bora, Southerly Burster.
Chinook winds melt snow in winter in the Prairies region, aiding wheat growth.
Fohn winds are dry and warm, melting ice in the Alps Mountains.
Berg of Natal descends from Drakensberg Mountains in South Africa.
Chiperone winds descend from Chiperone Mountain in Mozambique, bringing drizzles and low temperatures to southern Malawi.

subsections.title: Depressions
subsections.content: Two types of depressions:
points: Hot winds: hot and dusty.
Cold winds.

subsections.title: Breezes
subsections.content: Breezes are currents of air developing in coastal areas caused by temperature differences between land and water.
points: Land Breeze: air moves from land to sea at night because land cools faster than water.
Sea Breeze: air moves from sea to land during the day because land heats faster than water.

subsections.title: Mountain and Valley Breezes
subsections.content: Local winds that occur in mountainous regions due to temperature differences.
points: Mountain Breeze (Katabatic Wind): cold, dense air flows down slopes at night.
Valley Breeze (Anabatic Wind): warm, light air flows from valleys to mountains during the day.

subsections.title: Effects of Breezes
subsections.content: Influence of breezes on weather and human activities:
points: Sea breezes lower coastal temperatures and attract tourists.
Land breezes help fishermen go out to sea at night.
Sea breezes help fishermen return safely after morning catches.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the development of cyclones and anticyclones.
Explain the weather associated with cyclones and anticyclones.

subsections.title: Cyclone
subsections.content: A cyclone is a system of wind that rotates around the centre of low pressure. It is also defined as the region of low air pressure.
points: Cause: Cyclones are caused by the meeting of air masses at a front, such as the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) where trade wind air masses meet in tropical regions.
Direction: Cyclones rotate anticlockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere.

subsections.title: Types of Cyclones
subsections.content: There are two main types of cyclones:
points: Tropical Cyclone
Temperate Cyclone or Depression

subsections.title: Tropical Cyclone
subsections.content: Develops in the inter-tropical zone where trade wind air masses meet, mostly in maritime areas.
points: They follow a definite track and are rarely stationary.
They weaken over land.
They are violent winds causing great damage and death.
They are smaller than temperate cyclones.

subsections.title: Why Cyclones Rotate
subsections.content: Cyclones rotate because light air at the centre rises and heavy air flows inward, causing the swirl.

subsections.title: Necessary Conditions for Development of a Tropical Cyclone
points: Abundant warm, moist air at about 27°C near the sea surface.
Air blows inward and rises rapidly to great heights forming large clouds capable of torrential rainfall.
Outward flow of air at upper levels.

subsections.title: Development Stages of a Cyclone
points: Stage 1: Two air masses meet, causing a wave to develop due to friction.
Stage 2: The wave bulges into cold air, pressure falls, causing rotation.
Stage 3: Warm air rises over cold air as bulge develops.

subsections.title: Weather Associated with a Cyclone
points: Clear skies initially with little high cirrus clouds.
Cloud cover develops with progressively heavier showers as warm front passes.
Rain stops, wind direction changes, temperature rises and air becomes humid (warm sector).
Cold front passage brings rapid weather changes, wind shifts, temperature drops, and heavy rain for a short time.
After passage, skies clear and remain cool.

subsections.title: Examples of Tropical Cyclones
points: Hurricane in West Indies or Caribbean region.
Cyclone in Indian Ocean.
Typhoon in China Sea.
Willy Willies in Australia.
Tornado in Guinea and South America.

subsections.title: Life Cycle of a Cyclone
points: Formative Stage: Air masses meet.
Growth Stage: Divided into Immature (falling air pressure, strong wind, small area) and Mature (constant air pressure, extensive area) phases.
Degenerative Stage: Cyclone dies out, air pressure rises at the centre.

subsections.title: Effects of Tropical Cyclone
points: Strong winds cause huge waves damaging coastal areas.
Reduces land moisture, making the surface dry.
Causes destruction of property and death.

subsections.title: Temperate Cyclone
subsections.content: Formed similarly to tropical cyclones but differs in:
points: Formed by meeting of cold polar and tropical winds.
Develops in the temperate belt.
Covers a larger area than tropical cyclones.

subsections.title: Anticyclone
subsections.content: An anticyclone is a region with high air pressure at the centre. It rotates clockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and anticlockwise in the Southern Hemisphere.
points: Remains stationary before fading out.
Affects whole land masses.
Brings fine weather, calm conditions, and clear skies.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain how clouds are formed.
Identify the main types of clouds.
Describe characteristics of different types of clouds.

subsections.title: Definition of Clouds
subsections.content: Clouds are small droplets of water and ice crystals in the atmosphere.

subsections.title: How Clouds Are Formed
subsections.content: There are three main ways clouds are formed:
points: Convection lifting: Sun heats Earth’s surface, causing evaporation. Water vapour rises, cools, and condenses to form clouds.
Orographic lifting: Warm moist air rises over mountains, cools, and condenses.
Frontal uplifting: Warm air mass meets cold air mass, rises over it, and condenses to form clouds.

subsections.title: Necessary Conditions for Cloud Formation
points: Presence of water vapour in the air.
Presence of condensation nuclei (e.g., dust, smoke) to allow condensation.
Low atmospheric temperature (dew point) to allow condensation.

subsections.title: Measurement of Cloud Cover
points: Measured in oktas (eighths of the sky) using satellite imagery and remote sensing.
Estimated visually by observing portion of sky covered by clouds.
Weather maps and symbols show cloud cover amounts during forecasts.

subsections.title: Classification of Clouds
subsections.content: Clouds are classified by shape, height above sea level, and associated weather.

subsections.title: Types of Clouds Based on Shape
points: Stratus clouds – layered, flat, feathery.
Cumulus clouds – globular, dome-shaped, like sand nipples.
Cirrostratus clouds – thin sheet, milky sky, often with a halo around sun or moon.

subsections.title: Types of Clouds Based on Weather
subsections.content: Nimbus means rain. Clouds with 'nimbus' in the name usually bring rainfall.
points: Cumulonimbus – heavy convectional rain and thunderstorms.
Nimbostratus – continuous moderate rain.

subsections.title: Types of Clouds Based on Height
High Clouds (above 6000m)
points: Cirrus – white, wispy, feathery ice-crystal clouds; sky is visible through them.
Cirrocumulus – composed of ice crystals, patchy appearance.
Cirrostratus – thin sheet covering sky, halo effect.

subsections.title: Middle Clouds (2000m – 6000m)
points: Altocumulus – globular, water droplet clouds, arranged in lines or waves.
Altostratus – grey-blue sheets, partially or fully cover sky, contain water droplets.

subsections.title: Low Clouds (below 2000m)
points: Stratus – look like fog near surface, produce light rain, bring dull weather.
Nimbostratus – dark, thick, and shapeless clouds that bring continuous rain.
Cumulus – dome-shaped, heaped clouds with dark base, light showers and intermittent sunshine.
Stratocumulus – combination of stratus and cumulus, globular and low rainfall (winter clouds).

subsections.title: Clouds of Great Vertical Extent
points: Cumulonimbus – deepest, largest clouds with anvil shape, bring thunderstorms and heavy rain.

subsections.title: Importance of Clouds
points: Bring rainfall to Earth.
Regulate Earth's energy balance by absorbing and redistributing heat.
Indicate atmospheric processes and daily weather.
Reduce direct sunlight impact, preventing excessive evaporation and sunburn.

subsections.title: Clouds and Rainfall
points: Not all clouds bring rain – some have small droplets that evaporate before reaching the ground.
Rain clouds have larger water droplets that fall to Earth as precipitation.

subsections.title: Success Criteria (Precipitation)
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain forms of precipitation.
Explain how precipitation is formed.

subsections.title: Definition of Precipitation
subsections.content: Precipitation is a form of water (liquid or solid) falling from the atmosphere.

subsections.title: Forms of Precipitation
points: Rain – Liquid water falling from the sky. Most common form.
Sleet – Frozen raindrops that refreeze while falling.
Snow – Ice crystals formed in clouds and fall as snowflakes.
Hail – Solid balls of ice formed in cumulonimbus clouds during thunderstorms.
Drizzles – Light showers or small droplets of water.
Dew – Moisture that condenses near the Earth's surface, especially in the morning.

subsections.title: Necessary Conditions for Precipitation Formation
points: Presence of water vapour in the air.
Presence of condensation nuclei (e.g., dust, smoke) in the air.
Warm moist air must rise into the atmosphere.
Low temperature (dew point) must be reached for condensation.
Cloud droplets must grow large and heavy enough to fall.

subsections.title: Success Criteria (Rainfall)
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the formation of different types of rainfall.
Identify areas in the world receiving different types of rainfall.
Interpret rainfall data from various sources.

subsections.title: Definition of Rainfall
subsections.content: Rainfall is liquid water falling from the atmosphere.

subsections.title: Necessary Conditions for Rain Formation
points: Warm moist air must rise by evaporation, air mass convergence, or mountain uplift.
Wind must carry moisture into the atmosphere.
Air must cool in the atmosphere to allow condensation.
Dust, smoke, or pollen must be present to aid condensation.
High temperatures help initiate evaporation from Earth’s surface.

subsections.title: Types of Rainfall
subsections.content: There are three main types of rainfall:
points: Relief rainfall
Convectional rainfall
Frontal (Cyclonic) rainfall

subsections.title: Relief Rainfall
subsections.content: Formed when moist air is forced to rise over mountains.
points: Occurs on windward side where rain-bearing wind hits the mountain.
Leeward side (rain shadow) gets little or no rain, e.g. Chikwawa and Nsanje behind Mulanje.
Found in Malawi’s highlands: Mulanje, Shire Highlands, Dedza, Nyika, Viphya Plateaus.
Widespread, falls for long hours, more on windward side.

subsections.title: Convectional Rainfall
subsections.content: Formed by the sun heating Earth’s surface causing evaporation and rising air.
points: Air rises, cools, and condenses to form cumulonimbus clouds.
Falls in the afternoon with thunderstorms and lightning.
Heavy but short-lived (20 minutes to an hour).
Localized – small area coverage.
Occurs mostly in summer.

subsections.title: Frontal Rainfall
subsections.content: Also called cyclonic rainfall; formed when warm air rises over cold air at a front.
points: Warm air condenses to form clouds and rain.
Light showers falling for long hours.
Extensive cloud cover with storms but no lightning.
Covers a large area and can fall at any time of day.

subsections.title: Similarities among Rainfall Types
subsections.content: Despite different causes, they share some similarities:
points: All involve rising warm moist air.
Air cools to dew point where condensation occurs.
Clouds form and further cooling leads to rainfall.

subsections.title: Differences among Rainfall Types
points: Convectional – air rises due to heating and evaporation.
Relief – air rises due to mountain barriers.
Frontal – warm air rises over a cold air mass.

subsections.title: Interpreting Rainfall Data
points: Rainfall data is collected at weather stations.
Presented using isopluvial maps, tables, and graphs.
Isopluvial maps use colours and lines (isohyets) to show rainfall patterns.
Data analysis involves calculating mean and total annual rainfall.

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain environmental issues.
Explain the meaning of the term pollution.
Identify different types of pollution.
Describe the causes and effects of different types of pollution.
Suggest ways of controlling pollution.

subsections.title: Definition of Environmental Issues
subsections.content: Environmental issues refer to problems with the planet’s systems (soil, water, and air) caused by human interference.

subsections.title: Examples of Environmental Issues
points: Climate change
Environmental degradation
Overpopulation
Resource depletion
Wastes
Pollution
Environmental health
Acid rain
Greenhouse effect
Eutrophication
Desertification
Population explosion
Ozone layer depletion

subsections.title: Definition of Pollution
subsections.content: Pollution is the process of destroying the quality and purity of water, air, and land, making the environment unsafe for living.

subsections.title: Types of Pollution
points: Air pollution
Water pollution
Land pollution
Noise pollution
Light pollution
Radioactive pollution

subsections.title: Causes of Air Pollution
points: Poor waste disposal
Deforestation or destruction of vegetation cover
Bushfires
Emission of Chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) gases from equipment like refrigerators and air conditioners
Radiation from nuclear testing or accidents
Emission of poisonous gases from car exhausts and industrial fumes
Volcanic gases

subsections.title: Causes of Water Pollution
points: Industrial effluents discharged into water bodies
Breakage of untreated sewage systems
Oil spills from leaking tankers
Dumping of chemicals and dead organisms into water

subsections.title: Causes of Land Pollution
points: Poor waste disposal on land surface
Nuclear testing
Dumping of metals and chemicals on land

subsections.title: Causes of Noise Pollution
subsections.content: Caused by excessive sound that interferes with human and animal life.
points: Working machines
Manufacturing industries
Transportation systems

subsections.title: Causes of Light Pollution
points: Excessive illumination from advertising boards
Sports and entertainment lights at night

subsections.title: Causes of Radioactive Pollution
points: Nuclear wastes
Malfunctioning nuclear plants
Poor nuclear waste disposal
Nuclear accidents

subsections.title: Effects of Air Pollution
points: Respiratory diseases (e.g., tuberculosis)
Bad smell
Acid rain
Skin cancer due to ozone layer depletion
Poor visibility
Global warming and climate change
Disturbed hydrological cycle due to high temperatures
Melting of icebergs leading to ocean flooding

subsections.title: Effects of Water Pollution
points: Spread of waterborne diseases such as cholera
Scarcity of clean and portable water
Death of aquatic animals

subsections.title: Effects of Land Pollution
points: Loss of biodiversity
Shortage of land for cultivation due to land degradation

subsections.title: Effects of Noise Pollution
points: Permanent deafness
Loss of sleep
Nervousness and psychological disorders

subsections.title: Effects of Light Pollution
points: Disturbs people living near nightclubs or airports
Affects astronomical observations by making stars invisible

subsections.title: Effects of Radioactive Pollution
points: Health problems such as cancer, infertility, blindness, and birth defects
Soil sterility

subsections.title: Ways of Controlling Pollution
points: Proper waste disposal
Use of clean and renewable energy sources
Recycling resources to reduce waste
Enacting and enforcing environmental protection laws
Imposing penalties on violators of environmental policies
Conducting civic education campaigns on proper waste disposal

subsections.title: Success Criteria
subsections.content: Students must be able to:
points: Explain the meaning of the term desertification.
Describe causes of desertification.
Assess the effects of desertification.
Explain ways of controlling desertification.

subsections.title: Definition of Desertification
subsections.content: Desertification is the steady process by which land is degraded to produce desert conditions. It is also defined as the process of turning good and fertile land into barren and unproductive land.

subsections.title: Natural Causes of Desertification
points: Rain shadow effect of high mountains – the windward side receives rainfall while the leeward side remains dry (e.g. Chikwawa and Nsanje near Mulanje Mountain).
Existence of cold ocean currents – these reduce the chances of precipitation.
Continentality – coastal areas receive rainfall while the interior becomes dry.
Anticyclones – descending dry air leads to dry conditions.
Very high temperature and high rates of evapotranspiration.

subsections.title: Human Causes of Desertification
points: Overstocking that leads to overgrazing.
Careless cutting of trees.
Over-cultivation – continuous use of land depletes soil nutrients.
Opening up new farms (shifting cultivation) which causes deforestation.
Overgrazing destroys natural vegetation, exposing soil to erosion.

subsections.title: Effects of Desertification
points: Soil erosion.
Very poor crop production due to loss of fertile soil.
Poverty as a result of reduced crop yields.
Flooding due to lack of vegetation cover to absorb rainwater.
Depletion of water resources as rivers and streams dry up.

subsections.title: Ways of Controlling Desertification
points: Using alternative sources of energy such as hydroelectricity to reduce tree cutting.
Afforestation and reforestation.
Practising proper land husbandry techniques.
Controlling rapid population growth.
Conducting environmental awareness campaigns and civic education on environmental conservation.

subsections.title: Equatorial Climate
subsections.content: This climate is found near the equator and characterized by high rainfall, high humidity, and evergreen vegetation.
points: **Location**: 0°–5° N/S. Found in Congo Basin (Africa), Amazon Basin (South America), Malaysia and Indonesia (Asia).
**Climatic Characteristics**:
- Heavy convectional rainfall with thunderstorms all year
- High humidity and temperature
- Continuous rainfall; no seasons
- Dense cloud cover and low pressure
- Annual temperature range about 3°C
**Vegetation**:
- Layered: Top (buttress trees), Middle (lianas, orchids), Bottom (ferns, saprophytes)
- Evergreen, broad-leaved trees close together
- Continuous growth due to ideal conditions
- Examples: Mahogany, ironwood, rosewood, ferns, palms
**Economic Activities**:
- Shifting cultivation, food gathering
- Plantation farming: rubber, oil palm, cocoa, sugarcane
- Lumbering and wood industry
**Problems**:
- Insect pests and disease spread
- Thick forests hinder transport
- Tsetse flies affect farming
- Heat and humidity cause exhaustion

subsections.title: Tropical Continental (Savanna or Sudan Climate)
subsections.content: This climate has distinct wet and dry seasons with savanna-type vegetation.
points: **Location**: 5°–15° N/S of Equator (e.g., Mali, Ghana, Malawi, Kenya, Zambia, Llanos, Campos, etc.)
**Climatic Characteristics**:
- Three seasons: cool/dry, hot/dry, warm/wet
- Hot, wet summers
- Rainfall: ~762 mm/year
- High summer humidity
- Temperature range ~11°C
**Vegetation**:
- Tall grasses with scattered deciduous trees
- Trees shed leaves to reduce transpiration
- Umbrella-shaped trees with thick canopy
- Deep tap roots for water access
- Savanna scrub near deserts; dense trees near equatorial zone
- Grasses brown during dry season
**Grassland Names**:
- Africa/Australia: Savanna
- Brazil: Campos
- Guyana: Llanos
- Argentina: Pampas
- USA: Prairies
- South Africa: Veldt
- CIS: Steppes
**Economic Activities**:
- Arable farming, cattle ranching, nomadic pastoralism, plantations
**Problems**:
- Droughts, pests, leaching

subsections.title: Tropical Desert Climate
subsections.content: A hot and dry climate found in western continental regions with very little rainfall.
points: **Location**: 15°–30° N/S (e.g., Sahara, Namib, Kalahari, Arabian, Atacama, Mohave)
**Climatic Characteristics**:
- Trade winds are off-shore
- Very high temperature, clear skies
- Large diurnal temperature range
- No cold season
- Scarce and unreliable rainfall
**Vegetation**:
- Few or no leaves, waxy or needle-shaped
- Dormant seeds, thick succulent stems (e.g., cacti)
- Long roots for deep water
**Economic Activities**:
- Oil drilling, mining, nomadic hunting and pastoralism
**Problems**:
- Very hot, no fresh water, poor rainfall

subsections.title: Warm Temperate Western Margin (Mediterranean Climate)
subsections.content: Characterized by hot dry summers and cool wet winters with evergreen shrubs and agriculture.
points: **Location**: 30°–40° N/S (e.g., Mediterranean region, Cape Town, Southern Australia)
**Climatic Characteristics**:
- Hot dry summers (~21°C), cool wet winters (~10°C)
- Summer: off-shore Trade Winds, low humidity
- Winter: on-shore Westerlies bring rain
- Sirocco winds from Sahara to Mediterranean
**Vegetation**:
- Evergreen shrubs: rosemary, thyme, lavender
- Coniferous open woodland: pine, oak, eucalyptus, chestnut
- Woody scrubs in poor/dry areas
- Xerophytes adapted to dry conditions
**Economic Activities**:
- Viticulture (grapes), horticulture, flour/wine/fruit production
- Transhumance: livestock herding

subsections.title: Cool Temperate Continental (Siberian Climate)
subsections.content: A cold climate with long snowy winters and coniferous forests, found in high northern latitudes.
points: **Location**: 45°–75° N (e.g., Russia, Sweden, Canada, Alaska)
**Climatic Characteristics**:
- Long, bitterly cold winters with heavy snowfall
- Cool, short summers
- Precipitation mostly in summer (380–635 mm)
- Rivers frozen in winter
- Large annual temperature range (>30°C)
**Vegetation**:
- Evergreen conifers: spruce, pine, fir, birch
- Conical shape, needle-shaped leaves, leathery texture
- Dense forest, poor undergrowth
**Economic Activities**:
- Lumbering (paper, furniture, fuel wood, carvings, etc.)
- Fur hunting (fox, mink, beaver)
- Cereal and root crop farming (barley, rye, oats)
- Mining and fishing
**Problems**:
- Extreme cold limits farming
- Wild animal threats

subsections.title: Explain the Term Map
subsections.content: A map is a drawing or representation of an area seen from above (a bird’s eye view). It shows physical features like rivers and mountains, human features like roads and towns, or both. Maps help people understand places and navigate.
points: A map is a bird’s eye view drawing or representation.
Shows physical and human features.
Helps in understanding and navigation.

subsections.title: Components of a Map
subsections.content: The main components of a map include the title, scale, compass (direction indicator), legend (key), grid lines (coordinates), borders, and sometimes the source and date.
points: Title: What the map shows.
Scale: Ratio between map and ground distances.
Compass: Shows directions (N, S, E, W).
Legend: Explains map symbols.
Grid Lines: Help locate places with coordinates.
Borders: Edges or frames of the map.
Source and Date: Where and when the map was made.

subsections.title: Differentiate a Map from an Aerial Photograph
subsections.content: Maps are drawn or printed representations using symbols, while aerial photographs are real images taken from aircraft or drones. Maps have a specific scale; aerial photos may be distorted and show actual colors and details.
points: Map: Drawn representation with symbols.
Aerial Photo: Real image from above.
Map has a fixed scale; aerial photo may not.
Maps show selective details; aerial photos show all visible features.
Maps used for navigation and planning; aerial photos for detailed observation.

subsections.title: Types of Maps
subsections.content: Maps vary by purpose and features shown, including physical, political, topographical, thematic, road, weather, sketch, and aeronautical maps.
points: Physical Maps: Show natural features like mountains and rivers.
Political Maps: Show boundaries and major cities.
Topographical Maps: Show detailed land features with contour lines.
Thematic Maps: Focus on specific topics like population or climate.
Road Maps: Show roads and landmarks for travel.
Weather Maps: Show weather conditions for forecasting.
Sketch Maps: Simple hand-drawn maps with important features.
Aeronautical Maps: Used by pilots to navigate air routes.

subsections.title: Uses of Maps
subsections.content: Maps are used for finding locations, planning routes, studying physical features, showing political boundaries, disaster management, resource planning, education, and research.
points: Locate towns, rivers, roads.
Plan travel and transport routes.
Study mountains, lakes, and landforms.
Show political boundaries like countries and districts.
Aid in disaster and resource planning.
Support education and research.

subsections.title: Ways of Expressing Scale
subsections.content: Scale on maps can be shown by linear scale bars, statement (verbal) scales, or representative fractions (ratios).
points: Linear Scale: Line divided into units showing real distances.
Statement Scale: Words like '1 cm represents 5 km'.
Representative Fraction: Ratio such as 1:50,000.

subsections.title: Symbols and Signs on a Map
subsections.content: Maps use symbols to represent features such as roads, schools, rivers, and mountains. Conventional signs are standardized symbols used locally or worldwide.
points: Blue line = river
Black line = road
Triangle = mountain peak
Small square = school

subsections.title: Interpreting Maps Using Signs and Symbols
subsections.content: To read maps, identify features using the map key, measure distances with a ruler or string, and draw sketch maps using symbols to scale.
points: Use map key to identify features.
Measure straight distances with a ruler.
Measure winding distances using string.
Draw sketch maps with correct symbols and scale.

subsections.title: Locate Features and Places Using Grid References
subsections.content: Grid references help locate places on a map precisely, using four-figure references for large squares and six-figure references for more detail.
points: Four-figure grid references locate large grid squares.
Six-figure grid references locate smaller, precise areas.
Grid references use numbers and sometimes letters.

subsections.title: Distinguish Large Scale and Small Scale Maps
subsections.content: Large scale maps show small areas with high detail (e.g., 1:10,000), while small scale maps show large areas with less detail (e.g., 1:1,000,000).
points: Large scale: small area, lots of detail.
Small scale: large area, less detail.

subsections.title: Compass Points and Cardinal Points
subsections.content: Cardinal points are the main directions on a compass: North, East, South, and West. They are used to describe direction and location on maps and in the environment.
points: Cardinal points: N, E, S, W.
Used for navigation and orientation.

subsections.title: True North, Magnetic North, and Grid North
subsections.content: True North points to the geographic North Pole, Magnetic North is where a compass points (magnetic pole), and Grid North is shown by vertical grid lines on a map.
points: True North: Geographic North Pole.
Magnetic North: Compass direction to magnetic pole.
Grid North: North shown by map grid lines.

subsections.title: Other Map Skills
subsections.content: Additional skills include calculating areas on maps, locating places using bearings, and navigating using compass points and bearings.
points: Calculate areas of features on maps.
Locate places using bearings (degrees from north).
Use compass points and bearings for navigation.

subsections.title: Explain the term "Solar System"
subsections.content: The solar system is the group of heavenly bodies that revolve around the sun, including the sun, planets, moons, asteroids, comets, meteors, and dwarf planets. The sun provides light and heat at the center.
points: The solar system includes the sun and 8 planets.
It has moons, asteroids, comets, meteors, and dwarf planets.
The sun is at the center providing light and heat.
A planet must orbit the sun, be nearly round, and have cleared its orbit.

subsections.title: New Developments in the Solar System
subsections.content: Recent changes include reducing the number of planets from 9 to 8, reclassifying Pluto as a dwarf planet, discovering new moons and dwarf planets, observing pole shifts, and ongoing space missions.
points: Number of planets changed from 9 to 8.
Pluto is now classified as a dwarf planet.
Discovery of dwarf planets like Eris and Ceres.
Planets have axial tilts affecting seasons.
Pole shifts observed in Earth's magnetic poles.
New moons and small planets discovered.
Space missions explore planets (e.g., NASA's Perseverance rover).
Hundreds of exoplanets discovered outside our solar system.

subsections.title: 8 Planets and Their Characteristics
subsections.content: The eight planets vary in size, composition, and atmosphere, from the hot, small Mercury to the cold, windy Neptune.
points: Mercury: Closest to Sun, smallest, no atmosphere.
Venus: Thick hot atmosphere, many volcanoes.
Earth: Supports life, has water in all forms.
Mars: Red planet with tallest volcano and canyon.
Jupiter: Largest gas giant with Great Red Spot and many moons.
Saturn: Known for rings, second largest gas giant.
Uranus: Blue-green ice giant, rotates on its side.
Neptune: Cold, windy blue planet with strong storms.

subsections.title: Relate the Position of the Earth to the Sun
subsections.content: Earth is the third planet from the Sun, positioned to support life with suitable temperature and presence of liquid water.
points: Third planet from the sun.
At the right distance to support life.
Receives enough sunlight and maintains temperature.
Supports plant growth, weather, seasons, and human activities.

subsections.title: Explain the Shape of the Earth
subsections.content: Earth is an oblate spheroid, slightly flattened at the poles and bulged at the equator, proven by space photos, eclipses, and other evidence.
points: Earth is not a perfect sphere; it is an oblate spheroid.
Flattened at poles and bulged at equator.
Photos from space show Earth is round.
Ships disappear bottom-first when sailing away.
Earth’s shadow on the moon during lunar eclipse is round.
Different time zones, airplane routes, and star visibility support spherical Earth.
Earth’s shape causes different time zones and climates.

subsections.title: Explain Movements of the Earth
subsections.content: Earth rotates on its axis every 24 hours causing day and night, and revolves around the Sun every 365¼ days causing seasons.
points: Rotation: Earth spins on its axis every 24 hours.
Rotation causes day and night.
Revolution: Earth moves around the Sun in 365¼ days.
Revolution causes seasons and changes in day length.

subsections.title: Explain the Results of Earth’s Movements
subsections.content: Rotation causes day/night, time zones, and winds; revolution causes seasons, weather changes, and variation in day length.
points: Rotation results in day and night.
Causes sunrise in the east and sunset in the west.
Creates different time zones.
Influences winds and ocean currents (Coriolis effect).
Revolution causes four seasons.
Changes weather patterns and day length.
Sun’s position in the sky changes during the year.

subsections.title: Summary Table for Quick Revision
subsections.content: Key points about the solar system, new developments, Earth’s position and shape, movements and their results.
points: Solar System: Sun + 8 planets + moons + comets + asteroids + dwarf planets.
New Developments: Pluto reclassified, new moons, space missions, exoplanets, shifting poles.
Earth’s Position: Third from the Sun, supports life.
Shape of Earth: Oblate spheroid proven by space evidence.
Earth’s Movements: Rotation (day/night), Revolution (seasons).
Results of Movements: Day/night, time zones, seasons, changing day length.

subsections.title: Explain the Term Hydrosphere
subsections.content: The hydrosphere is the total amount of water found on, under, and above the Earth's surface. It includes oceans, lakes, rivers, glaciers, groundwater, and water in the atmosphere.
points: Includes liquid, solid (ice), and gaseous (vapour) water.
Covers about 71% of Earth’s surface.
Main parts: oceans, lakes, rivers, glaciers, groundwater, water vapour.
Hydrosphere = all water on Earth – in sea, rivers, rain, ice, clouds, underground.

subsections.title: Main Features and Processes of the Hydrological Cycle
subsections.content: The hydrological cycle, or water cycle, is the continuous movement of water through land, air, and sea.
points: Evaporation: Liquid water changes to vapour due to the sun’s heat.
